story:
Short Summary

Hello, my name is Courtney M. Leonard, a Santa Fe based artist and educator from the Shinnecock Nation of Long Island, New York.  Shinnecock in our language translates to "people of the level-land" or "people of the shore". Our men were whalers.  They whaled up until the late 1800s until it was banned off of the coast of Long Island.  Their travels took them across the world, sailing our vast oceans to ports in both Australia and New Zealand.  

The whales they logged, letters they sent home to their families, and images related to their endeavors have become points of inspiration and an acknowledgement of our shared memory of human experience to and from these waters.  This has become my embarkment in developing a new body of work that revisits and translates our cross-linked connections through mixed media works.  My intention is to act as “artist as curator” and “woman as whaler” as I make and place these pieces into a solo exhibition that explores the word BREACH.   

And so begins my first opportunity to cross oceans as I have been invited to participate in an international indigenous artist exchange for Kōkiri Putahi, at Kohewhata Marae, Kaikohe, New Zealand in January 2014. This new expedition affords an opportunity for international exchange of our innate response to material and place.  This would be my first entry to my own visual “whaler’s log”.  Your contributions to this project will help with all expenses associated with me traveling to New Zealand during January 2014. 


What I Need & What You Get

I need to raise $2500 dollars to fund this project. I will be gone for 3 weeks and will be hosted by the Maori people as a part of the artist gathering and exchange but I need to secure travel expenses. Airfare and rental car cost are roughly ($2500-$3000). Materials and supplies will also be covered by my hosts and I look forward to sharing my skills and culture with fellow indigenous artists and people who are also "of the shore".

I've worked real hard to come up with some unique perks for you. These include hand made porcelain bowls, sculptures, and original works on paper inspired from my "whaling log" and field research only available through this campaign.

In the event that our goal is not reached the remaining funds will still be used towards going to New Zealand but unfortunately may not include extended travel to some of the coastal regions of the area to research our whaling connections. 


The Impact

While there I plan to share the skills and techniques I have learned throughout my studio practice as well as the history and culture of my community. We are water people and I am sure I will meet other indigenous peoples whom have a similar connection.  This interaction will become an additional layer to the work as well as an opportunity for me to give back.

In addition I have been invited to be an artist in resident at the Museum of Contemporary Native Arts (MoCNA), in Santa Fe, New Mexico.  Upon my return from New Zealand I will begin the residency at MoCNA from February to May 2014. I anticipate sharing the experience of this exchange with the local community as it begins to weave into and strengthen my studio work.

Why "BREACH" ?

My work explores the evolution of language, image and culture through mixed media pieces of video, audio, and tangible objects.   There is such strength and beauty in language. The English language fascinates me by how many definitions one word can have. 

BREACH incorporates my role as a woman, a mother, and a current whaler of our visual culture.

For more information:

Exploring Intersections - ABQ Journal Article

PBS: We Shall Remain Video


Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that times may be hard and not everyone can contribute but you can still help by spreading the word and sharing this campaign with others. Please share on your Facebook and Twitter. The wider we spread the word the better the odds are I can reach my goal. 

Lastly I would like to thank you for your help and support from the very bottom of my heart. 

Tábütní (Thank you)  - Courtney 

Breach: Scrimshaw Study #2

Breach: Studio Shot

story:
Hi everyone, and thank you for visiting my campaign. My name is Radek Vizina, and I am a painter who has had work juried into the S.N.B.A. Salon this coming December at the Louvre in Paris, France. A little bit about me..... I have been painting for 13 years.  I have studied art in Toronto and New York, and I spend countless hours drawing and painting. I have taught for the Continuing Education department at the University of Western Ontario and have also spent time in Europe restoring Palekh icon paintings.  I currently maintain a studio in London, Ontario, and have an upcoming solo show in January at The Art Exchange, a beautiful local gallery with a growing national reputation.  If anyone happens to be in London in January of 2014, come check out the show!


 Now about the campaign.... I am trying to raise money for what could be a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity for me - one which I hope will kick-start my career by giving my work excellent international exposure.  I have been selected to exhibit 3 pieces at the Louvre this coming December and need money to pay for all of the expenses which an endeavour like this entails. The cost of entering the show alone is €950, plus crating the work, shipping the work, insuring the work, etc, and I would really like to go and be there for the opening to see my work hanging at one of the most prestigious galleries on the planet. For a living artist this is huge! The show runs for 4 days, which means that I would fly from Canada to France, and then return with my work, which would then be stamped with an official S.N.B.A. logo on the back side.  I will be exhibiting a tribute to Trayvon Martin (pictured) , a portrait of my 4-year-old daughter, and a larger piece about hope and youth. I am very excited! Getting accepted has been an enormous break for me, now I just need to get my paintings and myself there.


 As far as funding goes…..


The entry and administration fees are $1400.00 CAD. If I am able to go, then I will need a plane ticket which is roughly $1000.00, plus accommodation expenses which will be approximately $50.00 a night by 5 nights at a hostel, meals ($40.00/ day), personal travel insurance ($100.00)  and transportation while in France. I will also need a carry-on crate built for my work, which should cost $150.00, and insurance on the paintings which may run about $100.00. So all in all, with a little bit of wiggle room, just in case, the total cost will be $3500.00 CAD.
If I am not able to go, the entry and administration fees are the same, the difference being that I will need to ship a fairly heavy crate to and from France, plus have someone look after the work upon its arrival.  I cannot get any estimates for shipping as of yet because I haven't had a suitable crate built yet, which will be more expensive and much more heavy duty than the one I bring onto the plane with me. The crate alone will cost $300.00 because it needs to be built to order specifically for the pieces I am shipping and to air freight cargo standards. 


Now onto the perks!  I am offering my work - be they sketches, drawings, or paintings - to those who contribute to my campaign and help me see this fantastic opportunity through. All work will be signed and shipped to all of you who contribute, regardless of whether I reach my campaign goal or not. If I do not reach my goal and sending my work is no longer an option, or if I happen to surpass it, I will use the funds (or extra funds) to help pay for modelling fees and materials for the upcoming show in January.
Once again, thank you so much for visiting my campaign, and for taking the time to read this. You can also add me as a friend on Facebook to see more of my work.  Help spread the word! I hope to be able to report back on the success of having my work shown at the Louvre!

story:
NOTE TO CONTRIBUTORS: 

Please note that all perks will not be sent or delivered til completion of Campaign time has run out, along with all donations from these contributors, please provide full detail info in the comments section, name date and time you have contributed along with special request info including your email to discuss receiving your perks thank you!

UPDATE!

First donation of $50.00 made on October 3, 2013. 1 out of 5 perks claimed.

Second donation of $50.00 made on October 26,2013 2 out of 5 perks claimed.


Short Summary

Here is a bit of info on what will be basically going on with this campaign to raise money!

  • Hola everyone! Stephanae here, aka Maiden America, I have been in the art biz since I was a teen, now doing it professionally for the past 5 yrs I have now come to find a great nack and pleasure for it! I work as a freelance artist for myself, doing projects, commissions and non-profit donation work to various companies. On the side I also am a Founder/Head Editor for http://gigageekmagazine.com/. Doing anything from editing top writers for our up and coming online magazine to interviews well known artists and Cosplayers alike in the world of our fellow Geeklings. In the past yr.  I have come to find myself engulfed in the creative process of Costuming as a fellow Cosplayer. With a natural knack of ingenuity and creativity I to have started creating amazing costumes to portray the characters I loved and idled over during my childhood years into my adult life. Being that said, wanting dearly to show off and let others enjoy the passion as much as I do, started attending cons as a cosplayer, not just a fan of the act.
  • Basically this campaign means a lot to me due to the fact of wanting to give back to all of my amazing fans whom since the beginning as just being an artist strived to help me in every way they could to make my dream a reality of having the courage to do what for years I have seen accomplish so much with their costuming skills myself. This is a campaign for them, to be able to raise the money get the shoots and supplies to make what needs to be made to basically give the fans what they need the most!
  • What you all will be helping me to achieve is as follows,
  • 1). Building and creating the epic costumes I have promised my amazing fans I would be willing to do so ever much!
  • 2). Professional photo shoots of current cosplays in various scenes and poses for all contributers to recieve a limited set of.
  • 3). The accolades of reaching my goal, and spreading what I know I can do for so many people with the fan appreciation.  
  • REMEMBERING THAT WITHOUT THE FANS AND FOLLOWERS NONE OF WHAT I DO CAN BE POSSIBLE! YOU ALL ARE WHAT DRIVE ME TO SUCCEED! THANK YOU SO MUCH!

What We Need & What You Get


  • My basic funding cost I will need is $650.00 this money is soul purpose for supplies, photographers and shipping cost to give all contributors one hell of a photo print set to enjoy for all times being. Supplies consist of costume supplies such as worbla, sewing machine,machine tools, and fabric wear. The rest of the money will be to hire on professional photographers to gather over 100 different edited prints for fans to enjoy.
  • Each perk is different and unique as the last check them out!
  • PERK 1. PERSONAL EMAIL FROM MAIDEN AMERICA
  • PERK 2. LIMITED PRINT OF POISON IVY SIGNED BY MAIDEN AMERICA
  • PERK 3. BOTH WALKING DEAD, MISHONNE AND DARYL PRINTS SIGNED
  • PERK 4. BOTH VENOM AND CARNAGE SIGNED PRINTS
  • PERK 5. CUSTOM SKETCH OF CHOOSING FROM MAIDEN HERSELF
  • PERK 6. PERSONAL CUSTOM PRINT SET OF MAIDEN AMERICA (CONSISTS OF 6 PRINTS)
  • PERK 7. YOU GET EVERYTHING HOLY CRAP!
  • The funds, if not reached of the goal specified will still go to the photographer and not the cosplay supplies, this meaning all the fans will still receive sets, prints and hell even calenders! yes calenders! so no worries perks will still be up for grabs.

                     


Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't contribute, that is perfectly fine, just a simple comment of saying that you are willing to follow and support means more than anything! Just the fact that you took the time to understand, read and support me threw all of this is the best donation.
  • You can also share the indiegogo campaing page to other pages or your own feed as much as you want! thanks a million!

story:
Support Leah's Volunteering in Kenya and Upcoming Photography Book

Dear friends,

Educate a girl and you educate the world. When a girl is educated, the ripple effect is that she raises herself and her family out of poverty. Educate a community of girls and you raise countries out of poverty. This is increasingly essential as globalization truly unites the world as one. 

My name is Leah Lau. I am a photographer, writer and lifelong volunteer. I have traveled to all 7 continents and have dedicated my life to art and philanthropy to make the world a better place.

In 2014, I will volunteer in Kenya at the Daraja Academy for girls. I will be photographing the school, the students, the teachers, the founders, the volunteers and surrounding Kenya to help raise awareness about educating girls. 

  • Your support will bring infinite good into the world: Through my volunteerism and photography, I will help shine a light on the school and raise global awareness of why educating girls in third-world countries benefits us all. 
  • I will provide professional photos to the school's founders to help them upgrade all of their marketing, communications, outreach and fundraising materials including their website, blog, videos, brochures, and more. 
  • I have also been invited by the school's founders to produce a photography book about the school with them! But, first, I need your help to get to Kenya!

What We Need & What You Get

The communities of Kenya struggle with extreme poverty but getting to Kenya is very expensive. Help me get there and I'll include you in the book's Thank You acknowledgments!

  • If you contribute to my fundraising campaign, you can get unique perks like the fine art photos that I'll make in Kenya, Thank You acknowledgement in the book, and copies of the book!
  • The travel for me to get to rural Nanyuki, Kenya, where the school is located, volunteer on-site at the school, and photograph surrounding Kenya for 2-3 weeks, will cost a base of $7,000.
  • The money raised will go toward core travel expenses including the roundtrip from San Francisco to Nairobi, Kenya; room and board while on-site at Daraja Academy; Yellow Fever vaccination; Malaria prevention medication; photography and computer equipment; overland travel, lodging and food in Kenya; and visa to Kenya. 

The Impact

We are the change we seek in the world. Every contribution will make a positive difference now and for generations to come.

  • In Kenya, accessible public education ends at 8th grade. Most families cannot afford to send their children on to high school, which means that many girls from poor families are married off as young as 13 or are stalled out in lives of rural poverty. 
  • Daraja Academy interviews girls and identifies the driven future leaders of Kenya who otherwise would not be able to continue their education. Together, we can change the future of Kenya by raising up its girls and communities.
  • Many of you might remember the Cambodian Children's Book Project that I started in 2008 to build out the library for the ELMA School in rural Sambour, Cambodia. We reached success by 2010 and the school proudly had a library filled with hundreds of books donated by compassionate supporters like you from around the world.

Contributing and Other Ways You Can Help

Volunteering in Kenya is the next step in a lifetime of philanthropy and I would be honored if you would contribute and be part of the journey with me. 

Even if you can’t contribute financially, please feel free to spread the word to other like-minded friends and communities, connect with me about ways that you might be able to make in-kind donations, or volunteer with Daraja Academy or many other worthy organizations. 

We all need something to believe in. I believe that we have the chance every day to make the world a better place.

Love,

Leah

www.leahlau.com

https://www.facebook.com/leahlauart

story:
Hello. My name is Jill Enfield and I am hoping that you will consider donating to underwrite a project that is scheduled to take place in December 2013. I would like funding to join a group learning about the problems the area is facing caused by the pollution of the Jordan River. The organization, Friends of the Earth Middle East (FoEME) and a group of people of various faiths and backgrounds will be spending time along the Jordan River to discuss the consequences of pollution over the last century.

Perhaps you know me as a photographer and teacher, mainly interested in historical processes and I have been asked to join the group and lead a workshop. The aim of this project is to enable individuals to transcend superficial differences while engaging in a creative and spiritual process focusing on the Jordan River as a vehicle of mutual harmony. The blue colors of the photographic process known as cyanotype, symbolize the elements of clean, blue waters and blue skies and photogram murals by the river represent the common goal of bringing the river back to its pure beginnings. The different components of such a mural can include a variety of individually expressed themes using found natural and manmade objects, the human form, words and symbols from the area.

SO WHAT IS A CYANOTYPE?

The cyanotype --blue image on a white background-- also known as the blue print process, was invented and named by Sir John Herschel in 1842. Cyanotype is a perfect way to be introduced to a non-silver technique because it is very simple and inexpensive. Cyanotypes are made by using two chemicals: ferric ammonium citrate (the light sensitive chemical) and potassium ferricyanide (adds the color) to sensitize paper or natural fibers like cotton, silk and canvas or ceramic pieces. Cyanotype is a very easy process to employ; once the solution is mixed, it is then brushed onto paper or fabric and dried. It is a contact print process --the object is the same size as the finished product-- and the exposure is made with ultra violet light (sunlight) for five minutes up to forty minutes. After exposure, the cyanotype is washed in plain water.

The placing of found objects on a sensitized material results in a ‘photogram’. We can also use our own bodies, for example, by lying down on the paper.

A dialogue will be started with the participants on how to best show what is happening with the Jordan River, the environs and people. How can each faction help to bring together everyone so that all can still benefit what is necessary to life and what is considered holy by all faiths?

The pollution of the Jordan River is a universal concern. The aim of purifying the river or bringing attention to the importance to such an effort can be a unifying theme for this project and exhibition. The murals will travel to several synagogues, churches and temples to help bring this story to others around the world.

ABOUT THE RIVER:

The hugely politically sensitive Jordan Valley - which marks the borders of Israel, Jordan, and Palestine - is facing environmental catastrophe. Diversion of the River's waters for intensive farming and domestic use, coupled with sewage and agricultural runoff being discharged into it, has left the River's flow at under 5% of its capacity, and extremely polluted. Not surprisingly, this has resulted in the ecological degradation of the lower stretches of the River Jordan from the Sea of Galilee to the Dead Sea, largely contributing to the shrinking of the Dead Sea as well by over a meter every year. FoEME has been working for more than a decade to raise awareness of the state of the River, with many rehabilitation efforts already taking place: most pollutants will soon be removed from the River when several Waste Water Treatment Plants will begin to operate; a commitment by Israel's Minister of Environmental Protection to allocate 30 million cubic meters of water to the River, (a drop in the bucket, but a start) - but a real political commitment to return sufficient water to the River system, and to share it equitably in the region, is the real challenge. 

Rabbi Frank Dabba Smith:

“This is one of the most fragile eco-systems in the world, in one of the most politically sensitive regions.  With the peace process remaining at a very uncertain stage, the battle to save the River Jordan, more fairly share and safeguard its precious water from unsustainable use, provides a vehicle for practical action and collaboration across communities".

The trip and the art project will hopefully bring more awareness to this important issue. To learn more about FoEME, please go to: : http://foeme.org and read “About Us”.

WHAT I AM ASKING:

I am asking you to donate any amount from $5.00 up to whatever! The donated money will be used for materials such the cyanotype chemistry, paper and cloth to print on, and the cost of printing the pieces for shows, framing and postage. Then my expenses such as airfare, food and lodging and the materials for making your gift, and airfare and expenses for a videographer to go with me to make a movie of this event.

While everyone is attending my workshop free of charge, each participant has to pay their own airfare and expenses while there. This is what I need help with,to cover the videographer and myself. I will appreciate any amount you can give. And of course, depending on your gift, you will also get a gift in return.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN SUPPORT:

If you can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Please send this link along to your friends and family on facebook, twitter or just to your email contacts who you think might be interested in supporting me.

The Indiegogo share tools on this site can help get the word out!

Thank you for looking at my project and I hope you decide to fund it. No matter what, please pass this along to your friends and family. Thank you, Jill

Hello. My name is Jill
Enfield and I am hoping that you will consider donating to underwrite a project
that is scheduled to take place in December 2013. I would like funding to join
a group learning about the problems the area is facing caused by the pollution of
the Jordan River. The organization, Friends of the Earth Middle East (FoEME)
and a group of people of various faiths and backgrounds will be spending time along the Jordan River
to discuss the consequences of pollution over the last century. 
Perhaps you know me as a
photographer and teacher, mainly interested in historical processes and I have
been asked to join the group and lead a workshop. The aim of this project is to
enable individuals to transcend superficial differences while engaging in a
creative and spiritual process focusing on the Jordan River as a vehicle of
mutual harmony. The blue colors of the photographic process known as cyanotype,
symbolize the elements of clean, blue waters and blue skies and photogram
murals by the river represent the common goal of bringing the river back to its
pure beginnings. The different components of such a mural can include a variety
of individually expressed themes using found natural and manmade objects, the
human form, words and symbols from the area. 
SO WHAT IS A CYANOTYPE?
The cyanotype --blue image on a white
background-- also known as the blue print process, was invented and named by
Sir John Herschel in 1842. Cyanotype is a perfect way to be introduced to a
non-silver technique because it is very simple and inexpensive. Cyanotypes are
made by using two chemicals: ferric ammonium citrate (the light
sensitive chemical) and potassium ferricyanide (adds the color) to
sensitize paper or natural fibers like cotton, silk and canvas or ceramic
pieces. Cyanotype is a very easy process to employ; once the solution is mixed,
it is then brushed onto paper or fabric and dried. It is a contact print
process --the object is the same size as the finished product-- and the
exposure is made with ultra violet light (sunlight) for five minutes up to
forty minutes. After exposure, the cyanotype is washed in plain water.
The placing of found objects on a sensitized
material results in a ‘photogram’. We can also use our own bodies, for example,
by lying down on the paper.



A dialogue will be
started with the participants on how to best show what is happening with the
Jordan River, the environs and people. How can each faction help to bring
together everyone so that all can still benefit what is necessary to life and
what is considered holy by all faiths?

extremely polluted. Not surprisingly, this has resulted in the ecological
degradation of the lower stretches of the River Jordan from the Sea of Galilee
to the Dead Sea, largely contributing to the shrinking of the Dead Sea as well
by over a meter every year. FoEME has been working for more than a decade to raise
awareness of the state of the River, with many rehabilitation efforts already
taking place: most pollutants will soon be removed from the River when several
Waste Water Treatment Plants will begin to operate; a commitment by Israel's
Minister of Environmental Protection to allocate 30 million cubic meters of
water to the River, (a drop in the bucket, but a start) - but a real political
commitment to return sufficient water to the River system, and to share it
equitably in the region, is the real challenge. 
Rabbi Frank Dabba Smith:
“This is one of the most fragile eco-systems in
the world, in one of the most politically sensitive regions.  With the
peace process remaining at a very uncertain stage, the battle to save the River
Jordan, more fairly share and safeguard its precious water from unsustainable
use, provides a vehicle for practical action and collaboration across
communities".
The trip and the art project will hopefully
bring more awareness to this important issue. To learn more about FoEME, please
go to: : http://foeme.org and read “About Us”.
WHAT I AM ASKING:
I am asking you to
donate any amount from $5.00 up to whatever! The donated money will be used for
materials such the cyanotype chemistry, paper and cloth to print on, and the
cost of printing the pieces for shows, framing and postage. Then my expenses
such as airfare, food and lodging and the materials for making your gift, and airfare and expenses for a videographer to go with me to make a movie of this event.
While everyone is attending my workshop free of charge, each participant has to pay their own airfare and expenses while there. This is what I need help with,to cover the videographer and myself. I
will appreciate any amount you can give. And of course, depending on your gift,
you will also get a gift in return.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN SUPPORT:
If you can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help:
Please send this link along to your friends and family on facebook, twitter or just to your email contacts who you think might be interested in supporting me.
The Indiegogo share tools on this site can help get the word out!


Thank you for looking at my project and I hope you decide to fund it. No matter what, please pass this along to your friends and family. Thank you, Jill

story:
We have a vision for Canada. A big one. We see a nation brimming with culture, conversation and experience beyond any other. We see a nation basking in the societal benefits of pervasive creative experiences. We see a nation full of Artspoints Members who know that part of every dollar they spend supports the arts.

Artspoints Rewards is the vehicle to bring our vision to life. It is a national rewards program where Members earn points toward tickets to the arts and arts partners reap the rewards with larger audiences, great financial security, and therefore, more creative freedom.

We've run the numbers. We know we can make a huge difference. Did you know that another Canadian loyalty program generates over a billion a year in revenue? Just imagine every arts patron, every arts lover, every culturalista, participating in a rewards program supports the arts they love most.

Now that's social and cultural sustainability!

Simply, Artspoints is a membership-based rewards program that allows Members - people like you - to earn points and redeem them for tickets to the arts.

It's an innovative idea whose time has come. By using the power of points, Artspoints takes the tried and true model of rewards programs and applies it to the arts across Canada. Just like the airlines did when they were flying around with half-empty planes!

So far, we've partnered with 140 arts groups in the nation, and will have 200 on board when we launch.

This means Artspoints Members will be able to earn points when buying tickets to the arts and shopping at merchant partner locations. Points earned can be redeemed for tickets to any of our arts partner venues from coast to coast to coast. And when you redeem your points for arts performances, exhibitions and events, Artspoints pays the arts group for those tickets!

Can you imagine hundreds of arts organizations across the country seeing their revenue go up without taking their eyes off what they do best -- delivering creativity and making our world infinitely more interesting? Yes? So can we.

"A city without strong, consistent arts funding is basically a parking lot."

Douglas Coupland, Author, Artist, Vancouverite
Cities Summit 2012, Vancouver

The Impact
Rewards programs have had a huge impact on the marketplace. Major loyalty programs have millions of members and generate millions of points that they use daily for reward purchases. By applying this model to the arts, we are rewarding pro-social behaviour, which in turn can have a positive and transformative influence on the arts.

How often have you attended an arts performance in your community where there were empty seats? Imagine how much better this experience would be for the performers, audience and the company's bottom line if the venue was full! With your support, we believe we can take the power of the arts to the world and start filling those seats.

 

What We Need & Why We Need It

Over the past year, we have built a small team who are working hard to take this from concept to reality, and in that short time a great deal has been accomplished. Our arts partners can't wait for the program to go live, and we have a small, but extremely dedicated, Membership base who are ready to start actively using their card.

"Artspoints Rewards is a great idea, whose time has come. Through the power of the internet and the technology we have available today, Artspoints is going to deliver arts experiences to a whole new generation of consumers."

Christina Mattern, Manager, Marketing & Communications
Calgary Philharmonic Orchestra

Yes - Artspoints Rewards is a big program with lots of moving parts. And yes - we will ultimately need more than $75,000 to achieve our goals. But right now we have a set of critical hurdles to get past. A successful campaign will open the door to additional revenue, allow for growth and operating capacity needed to launch Artspoints Rewards. 

So, where will your contributions go?

  • To allocate additional resources to grow our merchant base
  • To launch Membership drive
  • To extend our reach to the French-Canadian market with bilingual website and marketing materials.

Above and Beyond

Reaching our $75,000 goal would be fantastic, so what happens if your contributions surpass our goal? If, through your support, our Indiegogo campaign raises more than $75,000, we will work hard to improve the Member experience, develop a mobile app, and much more!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute cash, you can still help! Like us on Facebook, pre-register to be an Artspoints Member at artspoints.com, or share this campaign using the Indiegogo share tools and your own social media channels.

 

Welcome to our Inaugural Hotel Partner

Artspoints is pleased to announce the addition of the Chateau Victoria Hotel and Suites as an Artspoints Merchant Partner. According to Mark Paul, Director of Sales and Marketing,

"We are excited to be part of Artspoints as an inaugural merchant partner. It offers tremendous value to us as a company and, equally important, allows our long standing commitment to the arts to be acknowledged in an innovative and sustainable way."


Located in Victoria B.C., the Chateau Victoria Hotel is the official hotel of the Victoria Symphony and a strong supporter of Pacific Opera Victoria.

 

About Us

Artspoints has been created as a double bottom line social venture. The company's mission is the development and establishment of an international loyalty program that in its operations provides for:

  • Sustainability of the arts
  • Greater access to the arts by all interested consumers
  • A positive benefit for all stakeholder groups.

Our wonderful and growing team consists of:

Sonny Wong, Founder and CEO
Charles Creighton, Vice President, Strategy & Development
Lenore Swenerton, Director of Product Marketing
Bobbi Davis, Director of Merchant Partnerships
Fane Tse, Communications and Outreach Manager

 

We thank you now, and the arts will thank you later!

story:
What Is Subconscious Development Motion Project (SDMP):

Subconscious Development Motion Project is an artistic collective centered around arts activism. Our mission is to spread awareness and promote critical thinking through making art that is accessible to the masses.  We use an array of artistic mediums and thrive on collaboration to bring our creative visions to life. As a Chicago-based group, the urban setting plays a large part in our aesthetic values. We believe in using “Gorilla Art” and “Grassroots” campaigning in conjunction with film, dance, and visual art to produce positive messages that challenge the forces of consumerism. Our work allows us to connect with our audiences viscerally and stimulate new thought processes. 

What Is "Simply Intricate":

Simply Intricate is a series of short works commenting on the value of nuance in life. The concept is simple, no moment repeats itself, each wakening moment deserves fresh perception. Its delivery is both unconventional and complex. Each contributing artist will use their perception of life around them to create art that allows the audience to connect with their senses, and indulge in the experience. Unfolding in a maze like structure of art installations, film, live performance, music and meditation, participants will be guided through an interactive multi-media journey. Along the way, layers of man made interest will be peeled back, encouraging a deeper connection with the world around.

Why Is “Simply Intricate” Important:

Simply Intricate is important because it gives us the opportunity to expose a unified way of enjoying the arts. We are excited to deliver a unique compilation of dance, film, music, and visual art that our audiences can experience with more than just their eyes. We want to remove the barrier that separates the viewer from the performer, and create an all inclusive journey that makes everyone in the space a participant in the experience of art. Simply Intricate gives us that chance.

What We Need:

Contributions will allow us to create the elements necessary in bringing this multifaceted experience to life.

We need to raise $3,500 for rehearsal/performance space rental, production materials, set construction, lighting design, costumes, technical equipment, and compensation of the technical crew and talent.

Breakdown:

Space Rental at Collaboraction:

Space: $1,000.00 for the week of show:

Hosting the event for four evenings and a matinee.

The set construction and configuration of the technical elements prior to the show. Event will take place May 2nd through the 5th.

 $18/hr for rehearsal time in the space(not included in the $1,000). Estimated $864.00

Technical Needs:

Projector: $360.00

Projector Rentals (2): $150 for 1 week

Sound Equipment: $180

Most equipment provided by artists.

Sound board rental- $180

Lighting: $210.00

Spotlight Rental $180.00 for 1 week.

LED Mood Lighting: $30.00

Materials (Set Design):

Paint: $80.00

SPRAY PAINT- $50 ( Black and white combo pack- $29.99/ Variety 3 pack- $19. 49)

ACRYLIC PAINT- 6 Primary color pints- $30.00

Fabric- 20yds- $30.00

Costumes: $200.00

Ply Wood: $75.00

Wire: $60.00

Promotional Needs:

-Posters

-Event Poster Cards

-T-shirts

-Hats

-Magnets

 Budget: $300

Our greatest concerns for these funds are in the space and projector rentals. From there we will map out our material budget using all available resources.

What We've Done.

SDMP prides itself in producing high quality work no matter the size of our budget. We put on events by using our own creativity, and making the most of our resources. Our network of collaborators enables us to pool together a variety of skills and create a full, multi-faceted artistic event.

We were able to help the 2012 Creative Nest's "Welcome to Our World" showcase reach its funding goal of $2500, and present our first multi-media dance piece “IN.”

Link: https://vimeo.com/38370796

We created a unique dance film as a public service announcement for the Foundation for Women's Cancer to promote awareness of cervical cancer and raise funds for their cause.

Link: https://vimeo.com/48856111

Our most recent event was a sneak preview showing at the Uncharted Books space. It featured some works-in-progress that will premiere at the Simply Intricate experience.

Link: https://vimeo.com/55817161

To view our other video projects, check out sdmplife.com!

Other Ways You Can Help:

Please share our Indiegogo page with friends and family members interested in supporting and enjoying the arts. Share this thread on social media sites like Facebook or Twitter. Five dollars can go a long way if people promote their excitement for the arts and get others informed about our project.



Use the Indiegogo share tools to help us!

story:
This Project is a 3 sided light box, measuring over 12 feet tall, with each side holding a high resolution, skillfully crafted digital art piece. The project is a collaboration between 8 artists.

We have incorporated the platonic solids of earth air water fire and spirit into each tier of the totem for a total of 5 tiers.

The its going to be backlit from the inside, so people can fully experience at night, and there are also going to be color chancing LED flood lights on the outside hitting the canvas, and the changes of color will be able to shift the tone and mood of each side of the piece independently.

At the base of the totem there's going to be a soundsystem in place, emitting isochronic sound frequencies that will assist in producing an actual physical and mental feeling through sound vibrations around the totem!

This giant totem will be a spiritual light beacon for all those who seek to evolve spiritually mentally and physically, and will serve as a meditative, transformative tool for everyone, incorporation 2d digital art, light, sound and construction into one package for a total transcendant sensory experience.

We are currently raising funds in order to complete this amazing project in time for it to premier at the Lucidity music and art festival at live Oaks Campground on April 13-15th.

Please help us to realize our dream and to share this experience with people everywhere. Every little bit helps, and together, we can create something amazing!

story:
In a joint collaboration between the New School and independent artist Janos Korodi, as well as the people of El Jardín del Paraiso community garden, we have created a mural. This mural has not only changed our neighborhood’s look, but also will allow our children will grow up closer to art, and closer to each other. Let us bring more public art to the communities! Come and enjoy it!

This mural, finished just last month, will continue to enrich our community for many long years. To help spread the benefit of such public works that will be with us well into the future, and to support this community garden and others, we ask you to contribute to the artist to support him as he commences his next project. Your donations will help to continue our community-based art project, bringing visual culture from all around the world to our neighborhoods.

 

Donate to our team and learn how the mural was created.

“To make the originals, I copied one of my paintings and mirrored it in the same time. My guiding questions were: how do the copy and the original work together? How do they communicate with each other? How will the copy change the original and how will they be simultaneously identical and different? They were also made through different methods, with the goal of creating an interactive painting session. I painted the left part of the picture, using traditional brush technique; then I encouraged the New School students and the volunteers from the garden community to paint the right part of it. This experimental way of creating a public art-piece like this mural transformed the original idea from a static, visual piece—the mural itself—into a new form of connecting people, an actual act of community-building, lifting us up to a new stage of being together.”  Janos KORODI

 

Check out the videos made by Alan LUPIANI during the work in progress:

http://youtu.be/dVPzuW_L4vQ

http://youtu.be/pDHrvAiovj4

 

 

More of Janos's paintings can be found at his website:

http://korodijanos.see.me

 

The mural is located in the East Village between C and D avenues at the 4th Street entrance of the garden.

story:
The Illegal Gallery is an ongoing series of spontaneous exhibitions bringing art otherwise unseen to light. We are an alternative art space giving artists a free platform for their work and the chance to show it in an unconventional way that will set them apart from the humdrum of the white-wall gallery space.

    We are also an alternative news source, I.G News, featuring current and contemporary issues and history in the Art World, expanding beyond that as well.

   We are open to painters, sculptors, video artists, film makers, photographers, architects, performance artists, musicians, spoken-word as well as written, journalists, etc…

 

    Bacchus will be a fully immersive art event featuring native New York Artists, as well as some international ones. The term Bacchus originates from Greece, and is formally known as the god of the Arts. We will be featuring a menagerie of works: paintings, sculptures, installations, drawings, music, writing and spoken-word, and much more. And we will be showcasing these works in a cotemporary manner; we want to provide a different type of art situation outside of the white-walled gallery space. Essentially, the Illegal Gallery hopes to celebrate the arts through the theme of Bacchus, which is a mix of cultural influences, a magical atmosphere, midnight summer dream, this Dionysus inspire theme will place a modern mythology right in NYC. 

Illegal Gallery wants to provide a different type of art situation outside of the white-walled gallery space, a once in a lifetime experience.

View our inspiration for Bacchus here!

 



    The Illegal Gallery prides itself on being a non-profit artists community, which is why we are asking YOU for your help.As funding in the Arts is decreasing in NYC it is important to support each other as much as possible.

We would appreciate any support you can offer us.

We are always looking for new Artists, fresh stories, to add to our open-minded and accessible artists’ community.

Wishing you the best,
The Illegal Gallery

www.illegalgallery.com

story:
*Some have been wondering why we are asking people to fund a new business. What exactly is the point of this project and why do we feel it should be publicly funded? I wish to make it clear that while yes, this is a new business venture, the *purpose* of the venture far exceeds any desire on my (Jason's) part to "get rich." We are specifically aiming to bring NEW gem cutters to market and to promote THEM and THEIR craftsmanship. This is not about me. This is about preserving and advancing the craft of precision gem cutting in North America. Will I make money on this? Probably. Will I get rich? Not likely. One cannot fund a venture such as this with no money and one certainly cannot pay the cutters a fair wage for their excellent craftsmanship with no influx of outside funds. 

If our goal of promoting and preserving the craft of precision gem cutting is to succeed, it will take all of us who are interested in seeing this happen to work towards that goal. We are asking for your support in this venture. We are not asking you to make us fabulously wealthy or to help us take over the industry and put other people out of business. On the contrary, we cannot see how this project can do anything but promote the general welfare of the entire North American cutting industry. The greater the public awareness of precision gem cutting, the greater influence and productivity everyone in this genre will have. 

If you have particular questions about my goals and hopes for this project, please contact me directly at jason@selectgem.com. I will be most happy to answer your questions. Respectfully and gratefully yours, Jason Brim.

What exactly are we up to?

(For those of you who like proper English, "Up to what exactly are we?")

The purpose of this project is to fund the purchase of raw, uncut gem material that will be given to precision cutters to cut and market to a wider audience. High-end gems and collector stones are a niche market--go ahead, ask your local mall chain if they have Benitoite. I dare you. 

Jason Brim started Select Gem in 2002, and loves him some pretty rocks. We'll send our select team of cutters the rough gems, and they'll cut it and post it on his website under their own names. That way, customers can get to know the various styles and tendencies of the individual cutters, and they can gain increased exposure in the marketplace. From there, they can launch their own sites and stores, get fabulously rich, and buy Jason's house out from under him. 

Okay, so we might not get filthy rich doing this, but we do love doing it. The curious irony of the gem world is that the glorious stones we read about, that are sold by the famous auction houses, that sit in the vaults of the one percent, that adorn the stars on Oscar night, are typically dug by dirt poor peasants or village co-operatives, and cut by dedicated individuals as highly skilled as they are poorly paid.

Precision gem cutting, in America and throughout the world, is a dying art. Seriously. It's mostly done by retirees, and them young whippersnappers can't be bothered to get off their iPads and pay attention to what makes it such a great art. Okay, that's a bit extreme. People of all ages do it, but there's a definite skew to the Boomers generation, and by some estimates, there are only about 200 professional precision gemcutters active in the United States. 

Part of the problem is shopping mall economics, namely that less expensive (okay, I'll say it: cheap) mass-produced goods flood out individually-produced, one-of-a-kind works of art (OOAK to you Etsy types out there). Chain jewelry stores thrive on repeatable, low-cost goods to make their wares. That's okay, but the end result is that both consumers and jewelry store employees don't realize that the spectrum for quality of cut goes way beyond anything they've seen. That's just sad. 

The airfare is already covered. So are the visas, translators, and ground crew. The website has already been built. The cutters are ready. We just need the shinies. We're looking to send Jason to Kenya and Tanzania with about $15,000 in his pocket, to buy needed rough gemstones for us to cut. That's where you come in. If we don't reach our goal, we'll still do the trip--learning the tricks of the trade from Roger (see below) is enough, but we have determined that the trip will be most cost-effective if we can bring back at least that much raw material.

Bring on the nerd knowledge!

Most colored gemstones (we're talking non-diamonds here, even though some "colored gemstones" are clear, and some diamonds are colored. Hush, you) that are sold in the United States are cut overseas by what many of us call "native cutters". We can almost guarantee you, sight unseen, that nothing sold in a chain jewelry store in North America or Europe was cut in the western hemisphere. Now, when we say "native cutters", that's not a perjorative term (neither is "native flora", right?). It's a descriptive term for people, generally near the original mine or in one of the big cutting houses in Southeast Asia, who cut the stones using what's called a jamb-peg machine.

Jamb-pegs have been used for hundreds of years, and given that everything is done by eye, some of the work is amazing. But it just can't match what a precision cutter can do with one of these:

Here's a quick example: 

Here's a Malaia garnet. On the left is the original stone: inclusions, missed meets, asymmetric facets, but still purty. On the right, the same stinkin' stone after a recut by Ryan Quantz.

Yeah, it's amazing. Precision cutters cut the best stone (not necessarily the biggest) that they can given a piece of rough. That's using the perfect angles to maximize both reflection and weight, a design that avoids extinction (black spots on the edges of a faceted stone), and one that maximizes the shape of the original rough and accounts for any imperfections in the stone. A cutter in a big cutting house simply cuts the size stone he's told to produce, like an 8x10mm oval. He gets no points for perfect meets (where three or more facets come together), and really, with NO magnification, why should he be expected to do so? Precision cutters, on the other hand, do make perfect meets, and have at least a 10x magnifier at all times to check their work.

Ethical sourcing

One of our goals with this project, and with Select Gem in general, is to ethically source our rough material. What does that mean? Why, I'm glad you asked. First off, if the mine owner insists you refer to him as "Warlord", that's a bad sign, but that's pretty obvious. We make sure the miners actually benefit from our trade, pure and simple.

Our Guide

Roger Dery is a world-renowned gemcutter and also one of the big brains behind Sharing The Rough, a documentary film product tracing gemstones from the mine, to the cutter, to the jeweler who sets them in heirloom-quality masterpieces. He has not only traveled extensively in East Africa buying rough, but has also a philanthropist supporting lapidary (you know, stonecutting) training programs in the area, so that the mining communities can cut the stones they produce. And did I mentioned world renown? He won the American Gem Trade Associaton's "Cutting Edge" award in 2007 and 2012, and you can see his work at Roger Dery Gem Designs.

This will be one of Roger's last trips as a guide to East Africa, and it's time to pass on his knowledge. Jason will be literally following in the footsteps of a master, and will get to pick his brain at every turn, and benefit from the long-term relationships Roger has established over the years.

The cutters

We already have a stable of excellent cutters lined up. Peter Torraca, Ryan Quantz, Alan Unangst, Donn Law, Hans Durstling, Larry Hager, David Cooley, Christiane Morin, Arya Akhavan, and Eric Hoffman have all signed up. We won't show you their pictures--you can thank us later. But they're real. More real than your "girlfiend in Wisconsin", that's for sure.

The risks

When traveling to Africa, there's always the chance that you simply won't be able to complete the mission: weather, local events, global politics, medical issues, etc. It's rare, but it could happen.

We could also get there and find out that some other group just came in and scooped up all the pretty rocks. The way to mitigate that is we're not just meeting with one or two agents, we have a whole mess of contacts in Kenya & Tanzania thanks to Roger. We also have back-up plans, like a trip to Sri Lanka.

story:
Svanubhava

Since 2008, a group of young and energetic artists and art enthusiasts (yes, that's us!) have gotten together every year to put on an Indian cultural event unlike any other.

What makes this special, you ask?

Well, to start with, we do it for kids.  Ok, maybe they are not all kids, but we target ages 12-25.

So classical music and dance for kids...that's not new you say?  Imagine this...3 whole days, an atmosphere completely consumed by art, over 75 of the country's leading artists, representing more than 10 different forms, presenting exclusively for 1000+ students from across 50 different schools.  Phew!!!

And it doesn't end at the performance.  They present their art forms, explain their rich heritage and point out nuances and intricacies, engaging in dialogue with these highly inquisitive and energetic students...the very students that form the future of this nation, and our world.

At a time where the youth are overloaded with information and access to everything across the globe, we feel it is absolutely essential to go the extra mile to make sure they see, hear, and fully experience the richness of the Indian performing arts...including the lesser known forms and harder to access ones.

Our aim is to create a lasting impression in the minds and hearts of these young kids, such that they develop an understanding, respect, and sensitivity to the performing arts.  After all, art is an integral and necessary part of the threads of society.

Our Initiatives

The team is working actively on a number of different initiatives that all spring from the same seeds of thought.

  • Svanubhava the Festival - having started in 2008, we have continued to refine the programming and scheduling of this intensive multi-day festival to try and get the greatest artists from across the country and the rarest of art forms to our students.  We have also worked with like-minded youngsters in different cities to take the festival to Delhi, Trichy, Bangalore, and Jaffna.  A few other exciting ones in the pipeline...!
  • Svanubhava On-the-Go - here, we have a team of young artists visit more remote and underprivileged schools, to introduce students to different art forms.  The students have the opportunity to engage and participate in a more intimate and familiar environment.
  • Svanubhava University - on popular demand, we have devised a day-long version of the festival that we can present at a college or university, exclusively for its student population.  This allows us to address a slightly older population of the youth.

Over the years, we have reached thousands of students, and several thousand more through the live festival webcast relay.  We are fortunate to have had the support of many extraordinary artists, who take great pleasure in addressing our young audiences.  We have also had a sincere group of supporters who contribute year after year without receiving more than a small mention of their name somewhere in the corner of our website (you'll never see a sponsorship banner at any of our festivals!).

And now we need your support - to embrace this vision, and join in our cause.  To help us bring this magnificent treasure of art to every boy and girl across every city.  Each penny counts and will help us go a long way.  There are also other ways that you can contribute to this cause.  We are always looking to grow our team of volunteers.  And we rely heavily on the support and services of different resources to make this festival happen.  Please get in touch with us at svanubhava@gmail.com.

Do check out our video and photo gallery to get a taste of the magic.  We have a few humble offerings in return for your contributions, but of course nothing that will come close to fully expressing our gratitude and those of the hundreds of children for whom lasting memories will be created.

On behalf of the entire Svanubhava community, THANK YOU!

story:
Short Summary

Dearest Community,

This is a simple project. Let's pool money to change the facade of the burned out Griswold's building.

Here's why:

In the summer our city streets start teeming with all kinds of people and Olympia welcomes them all; from age 0 to 122, from college students to drop outs, from state and city pros in their quotidian fix, to travelers and visitors staring about in wonderment, from the hard working business person to the most renunciate idealist, and to anyone and everyone in-between. Welcome. Olympia is a place for respect and love. Our greatest community resource is our human compassion and our ability to work together.

Here's what's happened so far:

In response to a tragic hate crime on the 300 block of 4th Avenue where a young man was beaten and sent to the hospital, a group of concerned citizens gathered. At that meeting, we considered the idea of using the facade of the burned out Griswold's building as a place to share positive messages for downtown. There were visions of rainbow stripes and language about love and respect for all. Cliff Lee, the building owner, gave his consent to move forward. We made a plan to replace the plywood facade and the PBIA board agreed to pay for the paint. We asked Vince Ryland, long-time local sign painter and muralist to do the sign painting work. Vince was featured in the recent documentary Sign Painters and is responsible for many of the incredible murals you see in our artful downtown. His beautiful landscape of the bay is the mural that we will be replacing. All that's left is to raise a bit of money to pay Vince for his work.

So easy! Can you help?


The perks?

Revitalizing a block of 4th Avenue that needs community support as it deals with issues of substance abuse, vacant properties, aggression, and hot spots for nuisance calls.

Championing a friendly, positive message that will reverberate throughout downtown.

Remembering that this is a place where we celebrate our differences by working together in good faith.

Making the most of the rainbows in the rain.
story_txt: Short SummaryDearest Community,This is a simple project. Let's pool money to change the facade of the burned out Griswold's building. Here's why: In the summer our city streets start teeming with all kinds of people and Olympia welcomes them all; from age 0 to 122, from college students to drop outs, from state and city pros in their quotidian fix, to travelers and visitors staring about in wonderment, from the hard working business person to the most renunciate idealist, and to anyone and everyone in-between. Welcome. Olympia is a place for respect and love. Our greatest community resource is our human compassion and our ability to work together. Here's what's happened so far:In response to a tragic hate crime on the 300 block of 4th Avenue where a young man was beaten and sent to the hospital, a group of concerned citizens gathered. At that meeting, we considered the idea of using the facade of the burned out Griswold's building as a place to share positive messages for downtown. There were visions of rainbow stripes and language about love and respect for all. Cliff Lee, the building owner, gave his consent to move forward. We made a plan to replace the plywood facade and the PBIA board agreed to pay for the paint. We asked Vince Ryland, long-time local sign painter and muralist to do the sign painting work. Vince was featured in the recent documentary Sign Painters and is responsible for many of the incredible murals you see in our artful downtown. His beautiful landscape of the bay is the mural that we will be replacing. All that's left is to raise a bit of money to pay Vince for his work. So easy! Can you help? The perks? Revitalizing a block of 4th Avenue that needs community support as it deals with issues of substance abuse, vacant properties, aggression, and hot spots for nuisance calls.Championing a friendly, positive message that will reverberate throughout downtown. Remembering that this is a place where we celebrate our differences by working together in good faith.Making the most of the rainbows in the rain.

story:
Kurz und knapp

                                                                                                                       (english version below)

Wir - Kerstin, Paula, Daniel, Max und ich - haben einen Plan und brauchen dazu Eure Hilfe. 

Wir schaffen einen Raum, wo sich Kreativitaet und Gesellschaft verbinden. Seit geraumer Zeit feilen wir an dieser Idee. Jetzt sind wir startbereit!

Mal's an! wird ein Ort an welchem sich Jung und Alt treffen um Keramik zu gestalten und gemeinsam einen inspirierenden Tag zu verbringen. Hier kann man neue Techniken erlernen, seinen eignen Stil finden und den Spass am Malen ausleben.

Das Konzept:

  1. Such dir dein Lieblingsstueck aus der Rohkeramik im Laden aus (Teller, Tassen, Fliesen, Schuesseln uvm.)
  2. Finde deine Lieblingsfarben
  3. Entscheide dich fuer eine Technik, die dir gefaellt (Mosaik, Blasen, Stempel, ...)
  4. Male, probier dich aus, stempel und wenn du nicht weiter weisst, wir helfen gern!
  5. Wir brennen dein Lieblingsstueck und du haeltst nach wenigen Tagen dein selbst gestaltetes Exemplar in der Hand
Wo stehen wir:

Der Laden ist gefunden und wurde komplett renoviert. Die Innenaustattung nimmt Gestalt an.
Der Laden in befindet sich in Löbtau im Gruen. Der Platz ist geschaeftig und reich an Familien und Kindern, mit Schulen und Kindergaerten in naechster Naehe. Neben Baecker-, Frisoer-, und Outdoorläden ist das Angebot für Kinder und Familien sehr spärlich. Deshalb schhafen wir einen Platz fuer:
  • Kinder, die sich am Nachmittag mit Freunden treffen, um gemeinsam zu malen und kreativ zu sein
  • jede Familie, die sich mit dem selbstbemalten Fruehstuecksservice oder der Kaffeetasse fuer Omi ein Highlight nach Hause holt
  • einen Nachmittagstee, um Baumschmuck zu dekorieren
  • Geburtstagsfeiern, Firmentreffen, gemuetliche Frauenabende u.a.
Jeder ist herzlich eingeladen auf der Kesselsdorfer Straße 36 in Dresden vorbeizuschauen. Damit wir uns keine Sorgen um das finanzielle Aus machen muessen brauchen wir deine Hilfe!



Was wir brauchen und was du davon hast!

Wir brauchen euch um Bekannt zu werden. Macht Werbung fuer uns bei euren Freunden, Bekannten und Familie.
Außerdem brauch wir eure Hilfe, um den Laden mit allem auszustatten, was noetig ist:
- Innenleben und Start up Equipment (Keramik, Farben, Kassensystem etc)
- Brennofen
- Werbekosten (u.a. Homepage)
Dein Gewinn:
Zu allererst (und am allerwichtigsten) wollen wir uns bei euch fuer die Hilfe und Unterstuetzung bedanken, unser Vorhaben zu verwirklichen. Ein kleines Dankeschoen wartet natuerlich trotzdem auf euch. Viele liebevoll bemalte Einzelteile werden euer Herz mit Freude erfuellen

Was es uns bedeutet

Kurz und buendig:
Wir wollen Menschen zusammenbringen und das Freizeitangebot für groß und klein in Dresden und Löbtau vergroeßern.
Wir wollen dass sich viele mit Spass und Farbe auszudruecken
Wir wollen, dass alle schoene Erinnerungen mit nach Hause nehmen

    Andere Wege zu Helfen

    Nicht jeder hat die Moeglichkeit uns finanziell zu unterstuetzen, aber wenn euch unsere Idee gefaellt - erzaehlt es weiter. Wenn sie euch nicht gefaellt, schreibt uns, gebt uns Tips, was wir verbessern koennen

    Ein dickes Dankeschoen von uns allen fuer Eure wunderbare Hilfe

    Kerstin, Paula, Daniel, Max und Suse

    ****************************************************************************

    ENGLISH VERSION


    Short Summary

    We - Kerstin, Paula, Daniel, Max and me - want to start a business that combines the joy of creativity with the joy of community. We all live in Dresden (Germany) and have developed the idea of our small business over the last year. Now we have found a location from where it can begin. 

    Paint it! will be a place where young and old will gather and paint together. Whether you need a gift for grandma or want to fill your shelves with self made, unique items. This place is for you. 
    Here you can paint your own pottery, learn different techniques and find your own style. 

    1. Select a piece of pottery (plates, mugs, decoratives, flagstones, bowls ...)
    2. Select your favorite colours
    3. Select your favorite technique
    4. Start to paint, print and stamp your own ideas while developing your style and learning new techniques with the help of our first hand experience
    5. We will fire your piece in our oven - you can collect it a few days later

    The location of the studio is to be set in a pleasant, green neighbourhood with schools, kindergartens and family housing all nearby.

    Our vision for the studio is to create an environment:-

    • for children, to gather with friends and enjoy painting. 
    • for every family which will experience a highlight when collecting their self painted breakfast dishes or a coffee cup for grandma. 
    • of creative possibilities, where you can stamp your babies foot on a flagstone. You will never forget how small they once were.
    • for having an afternoon tea and design tree decorations for next Christmas.
    • in which celebrate birthdays and other festivities
    • where people young and old, can get together, to spend an inspiring afternoon expressing their creative sides

    Now we need your help!!!

    ****************************************************************************

    What We Need & What You Get

    We do need your support in spreading the news so that people know that we exist!

    We do need your support for financing the interior such as:

    - Remodelling the rooms
    - Furniture and start up equipment (pottery, colours, aprons)
    - The oven
    - Promotional costs (such as a webpage, flyers ...)

    What will you get?

    First and foremost we want to thank you deeply for helping us to making this dream possible. Since we live in a world where you don't get anything for nothing, We feel honored and are very greatful for every penny.
    Nevertheless - there will be perks. Of course :). 
    Various objects, designed and painted by us and other artists will fill your heart with joy!

    And no matter what - you will get what you have paid for, even if we miss the goal.

    ****************************************************************************

    The Impact

    It is as simple as this:

    Bring people together
    Let them express themselves in any way they choose
    Let them take memories back home

    ****************************************************************************

    Important Shipping Information - international

    Due to the different kinds of perks we offer, please be aware of the varying shipping costs for different perks. We are aware that shipping is not cheap.

    For the Soy Bowl and the Egg Cup please add 3,45 Euro
    For the Picture Frame, the Rice Bowl, Humpty Dumpty and The Bavarian please add 7,00 Euro.

    ****************************************************************************

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We know, that not everybody is able to contribute with coins. But there are many other ways you can help us.

    If you like our idea - go out and spread the word
    If you dont like the idea - help us to get to the right track, we are open for every tip, criticism and comment!

    We do also answer all of your questions right below under Support 

    ****************************************************************************

    A warm-hearted Thank you from all of us!
    Kerstin, Paula, Daniel, Max and Sue

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Hello, my name is Terrance Houle my Blackfoot name is iinniiwahkiimah meaning Buffalo Herder. I am an internationally recognized interdisciplinary Artist from Calgary, Alberta and Kainai Nation. I work in several disciplines from film/video, photo and performance to music creation. Many of my works are in major collections such as The National Gallery of Canada, Elton John, National Museum of the American Indian (NYC) & Alberta Foundation for the Arts. Over the last 5 years I have toured and exhibited extensively doing 28-30 events a year and artist residencies. I’m heavily influenced by my cultural background as a First Nation, contemporary culture, punk rock, skate culture, and my daughter.  I have forged an 11 year career with much diverse work.www.terrancehouleart.com.  As a single parent I have always given everything to my art practice and its impact on my daughter Neko who sees how hardworking a full time artist’s life can be. 

I am looking to YOU the amazing audience to be part of the creation of the new direction for my career. I will be working on two projectsGhost Days & Friend or Foe #5 that I will be creating in Dawson City, Yukon, Canada during my residency stay at the Klondike Institute of Art & Culture KIAC July 12- August 18th/2014. GHOST DAYS is the main project I am looking to fund via this Indiegogo campaigning 


GHOST DAYS:    

Blog: http://artofhouleghostdays.tumblr.com

This is a new project consisting of new written music for an EP available online for download in the fall, an installation, live recording, projections, photos and collaboration with local musicians & an eventual catalog. The last year has given me the opportunity to create music for the first time, writing, playing and singing with my last musical/installation project Markham: Things even a drunk will never forget (link). I have decided to tackle a second project expanding my ideas on ghosts, love, death, history and location to create wondrous artworks that can be enjoyed on several levels.  I will be working exclusively at the historical Macaulay House (KIAC) for 5 weeks immersing myself in wiring and creating 5 new songs based on the historical ghost of the house along with my own personal ghosts that haunt the place. I spent 2 weeks in March of 2014 at the Macaulay house doing research for Friend or foe #5, I came across the stories of people being haunted within the house, and the film maker resident at that time had a very scary experience.  I delved deeper into the house and the journals left by other participants. Reading their encounters or non-encounters was inspiring for me, as I have deep love of history. I realized that many of the people in the journals where former friends of mine who I had intimate relationships with over 20 years, some good some bad, these became one of the Haunting aspects of the place for me. In this project I am looking to write 5 songs for a live performance installation held at the end of my 5 week residency inside the house. I will be working with local musicians to create this event which will include visuals in video and a “blackout” of the house since it is daytime 24 hours at this time of year. The project will culminate in live recordings, photo documentation for a catalog and video documentation.  I will be offering this new work in the fall with each person over $100 contribution to get exclusive first access to material. This is a new direction in my practice of creating work outside of my previous body of work. I’m asking YOU the audience to help me with costs towards this creation. I will be fully immersed in this project and Friend or Foe #5 and with your contribution you will directly fund this awesome new direction. This will allow me explore my dreams of eventually creating something larger as a full album and feature work. 

IMPACT

I am an artist who has always invested in himself since I started this adventure 11 years ago; I have always put everything into production of new works. I have relied heavily on sales or artist fees and YOU the audience for funding my projects. I am looking to raise $5,000.00 to help with production of the work GHOST DAYS while I am in Dawson City, Yukon. The funding is going to help with costs of living and working exclusively on these projects, it will go to travel, research, food, rental of instruments and payment to musicians and other artists working with me on this project. It will offset my living expenses from being away from home and my daughter who is staying with my parents on their horse ranch. The core funding from this Indiegogo campaign will allow me that freedom to create and thus give you a product that will be available first to YOU the funder and then available this fall to public audiences. I have always had the best reputation of putting 120% into my projects and pushing those projects to be available at good cost to audiences not just private collectors or institutions. The fact that this will be my first Indiegogo crowd source funding makes me excited that fans of my work can directly impact this new direction for me. 

As a pledge I have offered up for the first time postcards of my highly sought after work, mainly the URBAN INDIAN series, so for the first time this will be available with a $100 contribution. I have my wonderful full colour photo poster set of National Indian Leg Wrestling League of North America available which is definitely a collectible. Also for the first time I have my iinniiwahkiimah Vinyl Decal 12 inch (dipping black buffalo vinyl decal) up for grabs.

I have forged a career out of working hard, touring as much as I can and putting everything I have into producing unique and personal work. My track record speaks for its self from my website and my CV with shows and work all over the world consistently touring in solo and group shows. I am an accomplished award winning artist and I am PROUD to have forged a close tie to my audiences and reach out directly to YOU to help continue these amazing works.

The challenge with this project is my venture into music fully; I have always loved music and audio works. When my daughter was born 10 years ago I took up the guitar as a hobby and singing so I can share the music I loved with Neko. Ten years later I have finally decided to challenge myself with yet another direction. Learning music over the years and collaborating with amazing friends and colleagues has pushed me to make my own music. 

Please FUND this project. YOU the audience will never regret being part of a great project with Haunting effects.
